stem: A 6-year-old child with a history of asthma is brought to the emergency department with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial nursing intervention?

options.text: Administer a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) via nebulizer.
Administer oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 > 94%.

rationale.correct: Administering a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) such as albuterol is the first-line treatment for acute asthma exacerbations to quickly open the airways and improve breathing.
rationale.mnemonic: ABC - Airway, Breathing, Circulation. In asthma, focus on opening the Airway first.
rationale.incorrect: While oxygen administration is important, it is secondary to bronchodilation in an acute asthma exacerbation. Albuterol will help open the airways to allow for better oxygenation. Corticosteroids are important for reducing inflammation, but they take longer to have an effect than a SABA. Assessing peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) is useful for monitoring asthma control, but it is not the priority intervention during an acute exacerbation.
rationale.questionTrap: The question traps the test taker into thinking about oxygenation first, but bronchodilation is the priority.
clinicalPearls: In acute asthma exacerbations, bronchodilators are the priority.
Assess respiratory status frequently after interventions.

itemContext.sbar: S: Alex Johnson, 6-year-old male, presents with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. History of asthma. B: Mother reports symptoms started this morning and have progressively worsened. No fever. A: Increased wheezing, respiratory rate 32, SpO2 90% on room air. P: Requesting orders for asthma exacerbation management.
